skill.name: golang-pro
skill.description: Use when building Go applications requiring concurrent programming, microservices architecture, or high-performance systems. Invoke for goroutines, channels, Go generics, gRPC integration.
skill.summary: Use when building Go applications requiring concurrent programming, microservices architecture, or h...
skill.author: jeffallan

security_audit.summary: Documentation skill with legitimate Go programming patterns. All 195 static findings are false positives triggered by code examples in markdown files. No malicious intent detected.

medium_findings.title: Documentation Code Examples Detected as Shell Commands
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged shell command syntax in markdown documentation as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution'. These are legitimate Go build commands and tooling examples (e.g., go mod init, go build) within code blocks, not executable malicious code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All flagged patterns are Go code examples within markdown documentation blocks. No actual shell execution occurs - these are instructional examples for Go tooling.

medium_findings.title: Dynamic Import Patterns in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected 'Dynamic import() expression' patterns in documentation files. These are TypeScript/JavaScript code examples within markdown documentation, not actual executable code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Patterns are code examples within markdown documentation blocks, not actual dynamic imports in executable code.

medium_findings.title: Network Patterns in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected hardcoded IP addresses and network patterns. These are network configuration examples in documentation, not actual network code.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Hardcoded IPs are example values in documentation, not actual network code or credential exfiltration.

medium_findings.title: Filesystem Patterns in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected path traversal sequences and filesystem access patterns. These are file path examples and project structure documentation, not actual path traversal exploits.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Path patterns are legitimate project structure examples showing directory layouts, not exploitable path traversal.

medium_findings.title: Environment Access Patterns in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected database connection string patterns. These are configuration examples showing best practices for environment-based configuration.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Database configuration examples demonstrate proper secret management practices using environment variables.

content.value_statement: Building Go applications requires deep understanding of concurrency patterns, generics, and microservices architecture. This skill provides expert guidance for Go 1.21+ development with idiomatic patterns for high-performance systems.
actual_capabilities: Design and implement concurrent Go applications using goroutines, channels, and select statements
Create production-grade microservices with gRPC integration and proper error handling
Apply Go generics with type parameters and constraints for reusable code
Set up Go project structure with proper module management and internal packages
Write comprehensive table-driven tests with race detection and benchmarks
Optimize Go code performance using pprof profiling and eliminating allocations
limitations: Does not provide runtime code execution or compilation
Does not integrate with specific cloud providers or deployment platforms
Does not generate complete microservices from specifications
Requires user to apply patterns to their own codebase

use_cases.title: Building Concurrent API Services
use_cases.description: Design and implement high-performance Go APIs using goroutines and channels for concurrent request handling with proper context propagation.

use_cases.title: Developing gRPC Microservices
use_cases.description: Create type-safe microservices using Protocol Buffers and gRPC with proper interface design and error handling patterns.

use_cases.title: Optimizing Go Code Performance
use_cases.description: Refactor existing Go code for better performance using benchmarks, pprof analysis, and idiomatic patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Go Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Go function that implements [feature description]. Use idiomatic Go 1.21+ patterns with proper error handling and context support.

prompt_templates.title: Concurrent Processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a worker pool in Go that processes items concurrently. Include graceful shutdown, proper synchronization with sync.WaitGroup, and context cancellation handling.

prompt_templates.title: Generic Utility Functions
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a generic Go function with type parameters that [generic function description]. Use appropriate constraints from the constraints package or custom interfaces.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Microservice
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a complete gRPC microservice with [service name]. Include protobuf definitions, server implementation, interface contracts, and table-driven tests with 80%+ coverage.

output_examples.input: Create a concurrent worker pool with 5 workers
output: Go code implementation with WorkerPool struct
Function signature: func Map[T, U any](slice []T, fn func(T) U) []U
Example usage with int and string types

output_examples.input: Design a storage interface following Go idioms

best_practices: Use goroutines with clear lifecycle management and context propagation to prevent goroutine leaks
Write table-driven tests with subtests for comprehensive coverage and readable failure output
Apply the 'accept interfaces, return structs' pattern for flexible and testable code
anti_patterns: Avoid creating goroutines without channel synchronization or context cancellation handling
Do not use reflection for type assertions when type switches or generics are sufficient
Never hardcode configuration values; use functional options or environment variables instead

faq.question: What Go version does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Go 1.21+ patterns including generics (introduced in 1.18), enhanced concurrency features, and modern tooling.

faq.question: How does this skill handle concurrency patterns?
faq.answer: It provides worker pools, channel-based synchronization, context propagation, and proper lifecycle management using sync primitives.

faq.question: Does this skill generate test code?
faq.answer: Yes, it generates table-driven tests with subtests, benchmarks, and integrates race detector flags for concurrent code.

faq.question: Can this skill help with gRPC development?
faq.answer: Yes, it provides protobuf definitions, gRPC server/client implementations, and proper error handling for microservices.

faq.question: How are generics covered in this skill?
faq.answer: The skill includes type parameters, constraints (built-in and custom), generic functions, and generic type definitions with practical examples.

faq.question: Does this skill optimize existing Go code?
faq.answer: It provides guidance on profiling with pprof, writing benchmarks, eliminating allocations, and applying idiomatic Go patterns for performance.
